elements.content: The axially chiral conformations of 2,2′-bipyridine are, for the first time, captured and isolated in individual crystals of a new family of three-dimensional coordination polymers [Mn(II)(2,2′-bpy)(HCO2)2–x (N3) x ] (x = 0.3–0.7) upon an unusual spontaneous resolution. Furthermore, the Mn(II)···Mn(II) magnetic exchange can be tuned by control of the ratio of N3 –/HCO2 –.
elements.clean_text: The axially chiral conformations of 2,2'-bipyridine are, for the first time, captured and isolated in individual crystals of a new family of three-dimensional coordination polymers [Mn(II)(2,2'-bpy)(HCO2)2-x (N3) x ] (x = 0.3-0.7) upon an unusual spontaneous resolution. Furthermore, the Mn(II)⋅⋅⋅Mn(II) magnetic exchange can be tuned by control of the ratio of N3 -/HCO2 -.

elements.content: The axially chiral conformations of 2,2′-bipyridine are, for the first time, captured and isolated in individual crystals of a new family of three-dimensional coordination polymers [Mn(II)(2,2′-bpy)(HCO2)2−x (N3) x ] (x = 0.3−0.7) upon an unusual spontaneous resolution. Furthermore, the Mn(II)···Mn(II) magnetic exchange can be tuned by control of the ratio of N3 −/HCO2 −.
elements.clean_text: The axially chiral conformations of 2,2'-bipyridine are, for the first time, captured and isolated in individual crystals of a new family of three-dimensional coordination polymers [Mn(II)(2,2'-bpy)(HCO2)2-x (N3) x ] (x = 0.3-0.7) upon an unusual spontaneous resolution. Furthermore, the Mn(II)⋅⋅⋅Mn(II) magnetic exchange can be tuned by control of the ratio of N3 -/HCO2 -.

elements.content: Chiral compounds have attracted continuous and intense attention in investigations on the origins of biological homochirality and, more importantly, in fields of chemistry and materials for their potential applications in asymmetric catalysis, enantioselective synthesis, and as nonlinear optical materials. Inspired by the observation of the magnetochiral dichroism (MChD) effect exhibiting the relationship among chirality, magnetism, and light, the investigation of new magnetic materials combining interesting magnetic properties and optical activity has become a hot topic of recent research.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Chiral compounds have attracted continuous and intense attention in investigations on the origins of biological homochirality and, more importantly, in fields of chemistry and materials for their potential applications in asymmetric catalysis, enantioselective synthesis, and as nonlinear optical materials. Inspired by the observation of the magnetochiral dichroism (MChD) effect exhibiting the relationship among chirality, magnetism, and light, the investigation of new magnetic materials combining interesting magnetic properties and optical activity has become a hot topic of recent research.

elements.content: Chiral metallo-organic hybrid materials can usually be produced either from using enantiopure organic ligands as well as other chiral components or via spontaneous resolution upon crystallization from achiral or racemic ligands. Spontaneous resolution through self-assembly without involving any chiral ligands or chiral auxiliaries is an appealing approach toward chiral materials, since no expensive enantiopure precursors are required. Although it is well-known that supramolecular interactions, for example metal–ligand coordination interactions, hydrogen bonding, and π–π interactions, play a very important role in the assembly process, spontaneous resolution of metal coordination compounds is still rather rare in chiral synthesis, not to mention how to control and utilize such processes.
elements.clean_text: Chiral metallo-organic hybrid materials can usually be produced either from using enantiopure organic ligands as well as other chiral components or via spontaneous resolution upon crystallization from achiral or racemic ligands. Spontaneous resolution through self-assembly without involving any chiral ligands or chiral auxiliaries is an appealing approach toward chiral materials, since no expensive enantiopure precursors are required. Although it is well-known that supramolecular interactions, for example metal-ligand coordination interactions, hydrogen bonding, and π-π interactions, play a very important role in the assembly process, spontaneous resolution of metal coordination compounds is still rather rare in chiral synthesis, not to mention how to control and utilize such processes.

elements.content: In organic chemistry, elements of chirality include chiral centers, chiral axes, and the chiral plane. The chiral nature of ligands, along with the formation of chiral conformations or helical structures upon coordination, gives rise to inherent and/or supramolecular chirality in coordination compounds. Chiral compounds with stereogenic centers are common, e.g. chiral carbon atoms or metal centers in tetrahedral or octahedral geometries with different ligands. Axial and planar chirality can originate from steric hindrance or be fixed upon covalent or coordination bonding. For example, 1,1′-binaphthalene is achiral, due to the free rotation of a σ-bond between two naphthalene rings; nonetheless, bulky substituted BINAP (2,2′-bis(diphenylphosphino)-1,1′-binaphthyl) is a chiral ligand widely used in asymmetric synthesis. Apparently, the bulky substituents restrict the free rotation between the naphthalene rings and introduce the axial chirality. A few examples of synthesizing axially chiral organic compounds have been reported so far.
elements.clean_text: In organic chemistry, elements of chirality include chiral centers, chiral axes, and the chiral plane. The chiral nature of ligands, along with the formation of chiral conformations or helical structures upon coordination, gives rise to inherent and/or supramolecular chirality in coordination compounds. Chiral compounds with stereogenic centers are common, e.g. chiral carbon atoms or metal centers in tetrahedral or octahedral geometries with different ligands. Axial and planar chirality can originate from steric hindrance or be fixed upon covalent or coordination bonding. For example, 1,1'-binaphthalene is achiral, due to the free rotation of a σ-bond between two naphthalene rings; nonetheless, bulky substituted BINAP (2,2'-bis(diphenylphosphino)-1,1'-binaphthyl) is a chiral ligand widely used in asymmetric synthesis. Apparently, the bulky substituents restrict the free rotation between the naphthalene rings and introduce the axial chirality. A few examples of synthesizing axially chiral organic compounds have been reported so far.

elements.content: 2,2′-Bipyridine (2,2′-bpy) is a similar case to 1,1′-binaphthalene in that the two pyridine rings can rotate easily without bulky steric hindrance. It is very difficult, if not impossible, to separate the two conformations of λ and δ for the free ligand because of the small energy barrier for cis/trans interconversion (∼6 kJ mol–1). The 2,2′-bpy moiety shows coplanar rings with nitrogen in the cis-positions upon chelation. To our knowledge, no coordination polymers bearing axially chiral moieties of 2,2′-bpy have been isolated, especially via spontaneous resolution. Herein, we utilized this simple achiral ligand and isolated a family of 3-dimensional chiral frameworks [Mn(II)(2,2′-bpy)(HCO2)2–x (N3) x ] by spontaneous resolution from solution reactions. The ratio of the three-atom bridges, i.e. azide to formate, is tunable, owning to the substitutional disorder. Though the coordination spheres of metal atoms cannot be unambiguously figured out as stereogenic centers, the conformations of 2,2′-bpy are fixed with axial chirality. Each individual crystal possesses only one conformation (λ or δ) of 2,2′-bpy in it, and the Cotton effect was observed. Furthermore, the magnetic exchange can be tuned through the adjustable magnetic coupling pathways.
elements.clean_text: 2,2'-Bipyridine (2,2'-bpy) is a similar case to 1,1'-binaphthalene in that the two pyridine rings can rotate easily without bulky steric hindrance. It is very difficult, if not impossible, to separate the two conformations of λ and δ for the free ligand because of the small energy barrier for cis/trans interconversion (~6 kJ mol-1). The 2,2'-bpy moiety shows coplanar rings with nitrogen in the cis-positions upon chelation. To our knowledge, no coordination polymers bearing axially chiral moieties of 2,2'-bpy have been isolated, especially via spontaneous resolution. Herein, we utilized this simple achiral ligand and isolated a family of 3-dimensional chiral frameworks [Mn(II)(2,2'-bpy)(HCO2)2-x (N3) x ] by spontaneous resolution from solution reactions. The ratio of the three-atom bridges, i.e. azide to formate, is tunable, owning to the substitutional disorder. Though the coordination spheres of metal atoms cannot be unambiguously figured out as stereogenic centers, the conformations of 2,2'-bpy are fixed with axial chirality. Each individual crystal possesses only one conformation (λ or δ) of 2,2'-bpy in it, and the Cotton effect was observed. Furthermore, the magnetic exchange can be tuned through the adjustable magnetic coupling pathways.

elements.content: The reagents and solvents used were commercially available and used as received without further purification. All preparations and manipulations were performed under aerobic conditions. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with an Elementar Vario-EL CHNS elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm–1 with a Bruker-EQUINOX 55 FT-IR spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (pXRD) intensities for polycrystalline samples were measured at room temperature on a Bruker D8 Advance diffratometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.54056 Å) by scanning over the range 5–60° with step 0.2°/s. The calculated patterns were generated with Mercury. Magnetic measurements were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS XL-7 SQUID magnetometer. The samples were sealed in parafilm to avoid any orientation of the crystallites.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

The reagents and solvents used were commercially available and used as received without further purification. All preparations and manipulations were performed under aerobic conditions. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with an Elementar Vario-EL CHNS elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1 with a Bruker-EQUINOX 55 FT-IR spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (pXRD) intensities for polycrystalline samples were measured at room temperature on a Bruker D8 Advance diffratometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.54056 Å) by scanning over the range 5-60° with step 0.2°/s. The calculated patterns were generated with Mercury. Magnetic measurements were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS XL-7 SQUID magnetometer. The samples were sealed in parafilm to avoid any orientation of the crystallites.

elements.content:
Safety Note: Azide salts are potentially explosive. Only small amounts of material should be prepared, and these should be handled with great caution.

Synthesis of [Mn(II)(2,2′-bpy)(HCO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2–<italic toggle="yes">x</italic> </sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub> <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> </sub>] (<bold>1</bold>, <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> = 0.3; <bold>2</bold>, <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> = 0.6; and <bold>3</bold>, <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> = 0.7)

2,2′-bpy and NaN3 were dissolved in 20 mL of methanol in an ultrasonic bath, and then the mixture was added to Mn(HCO2)2. After stirring for half an hour, the white solid was dissolved and turned yellowish. Yellow crystals of 1–3 were obtained via filtration in ∼30% yield based on Mn(HCO2)2. The ratios of the reactants of 2,2′-bipyridine, NaN3, and Mn(HCO2)2 are 4:1:4, 3:1:3, and 2:1:2, respectively, giving 1, 2, and 3. Anal. Calcd for 1: N, 13.53; C, 46.80; H, 3.26. Found: N, 13.50; C, 45.21; H, 3.36. Anal. Calcd for 2: N, 17.78; C, 45.74; H, 3.16. Found: N, 17.53; C, 45.51; H, 3.24. Anal. Calcd for 3: N, 19.20; C, 45.38; H, 3.13. Found: N, 18.99; C, 44.78; H, 3.50.
elements.clean_text:
Safety Note: Azide salts are potentially explosive. Only small amounts of material should be prepared, and these should be handled with great caution.

Synthesis of [Mn(II)(2,2'-bpy)(HCO2)2-x (N3) x ] (1, x = 0.3; 2, x = 0.6; and 3, x = 0.7)

2,2'-bpy and NaN3 were dissolved in 20 mL of methanol in an ultrasonic bath, and then the mixture was added to Mn(HCO2)2. After stirring for half an hour, the white solid was dissolved and turned yellowish. Yellow crystals of 1-3 were obtained via filtration in ~30% yield based on Mn(HCO2)2. The ratios of the reactants of 2,2'-bipyridine, NaN3, and Mn(HCO2)2 are 4:1:4, 3:1:3, and 2:1:2, respectively, giving 1, 2, and 3. Anal. Calcd for 1: N, 13.53; C, 46.80; H, 3.26. Found: N, 13.50; C, 45.21; H, 3.36. Anal. Calcd for 2: N, 17.78; C, 45.74; H, 3.16. Found: N, 17.53; C, 45.51; H, 3.24. Anal. Calcd for 3: N, 19.20; C, 45.38; H, 3.13. Found: N, 18.99; C, 44.78; H, 3.50.

elements.content: The intensity data of 2-P was recorded on a Rigaku R-AXIS SPIDE IP system with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å); the intensity data of 1, 2-M, and 3 were recorded on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD system with Mo Kα radiation. Processing data of 1, 2-M, and 3 were accomplished with use of the program SAINT; an empirical absorption correction based on symmetry equivalent reflections was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved with direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares (SHELX-97). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. Hydrogen atoms on organic ligands were generated by the riding mode. Further details for compounds 1–3 are summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The intensity data of 2-P was recorded on a Rigaku R-AXIS SPIDE IP system with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å); the intensity data of 1, 2-M, and 3 were recorded on a Bruker SMART Apex CCD system with Mo Kα radiation. Processing data of 1, 2-M, and 3 were accomplished with use of the program SAINT; an empirical absorption correction based on symmetry equivalent reflections was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved with direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares (SHELX-97). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically by least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program. Hydrogen atoms on organic ligands were generated by the riding mode. Further details for compounds 1-3 are summarized in Table .

Reactions of 2,2′-bpy, NaN3, and Mn(HCO2)2 in ratios of 4:1:4, 3:1:3, and 2:1:2 yielded three yellowish crystalline compounds of [Mn(II)(2,2′-bpy)(HCO2)2–x (N3) x ] (1, x = 0.3; 2, x = 0.6; and 3, x = 0.7). The assignments of the occupancies and the ratio of azide and formate were based on both single crystal structure refinement and elemental analysis (CHN, obtaining x value by minimizing the residuals). By normalizing the intensities of peaks which were attributed to the carboxylate stretching vibration, the FT-IR spectra of 1–3 clearly showed the enhancement of absorption (symmetrical and asymmetrical stretching vibration of N3 –) followed by the increased ratio of N3 –/HCO2 –, in line with the result of elemental analysis (Figure ). Since different proportions of reactants can lead to different ratios of the three-atom bridges (i.e. the greater the proportion of NaN3, the larger the value of x is), reactions with greatly excessive or without NaN3 had also been tried. It is interesting that when an excess amount of NaN3 was used, yellow precipitate resulted, which was a previously reported structure of [Mn(II)(2,2′-bpy)(N3)2], with alternative EE (end-to-end, μ1,3) and EO (end-on, μ1,1) azide bridges in the space group of P1̅ (Figure ). In the absence of NaN3 or replacing Mn(HCO2)2 with Ni(HCO2)2/Cu(HCO2)2, crystalline powders other than phases 1–3 were obtained. The above experiments illustrate the spontaneous resolution process cannot occur without either of the three-atom bridges.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Reactions of 2,2'-bpy, NaN3, and Mn(HCO2)2 in ratios of 4:1:4, 3:1:3, and 2:1:2 yielded three yellowish crystalline compounds of [Mn(II)(2,2'-bpy)(HCO2)2-x (N3) x ] (1, x = 0.3; 2, x = 0.6; and 3, x = 0.7). The assignments of the occupancies and the ratio of azide and formate were based on both single crystal structure refinement and elemental analysis (CHN, obtaining x value by minimizing the residuals). By normalizing the intensities of peaks which were attributed to the carboxylate stretching vibration, the FT-IR spectra of 1-3 clearly showed the enhancement of absorption (symmetrical and asymmetrical stretching vibration of N3 -) followed by the increased ratio of N3 -/HCO2 -, in line with the result of elemental analysis (Figure ). Since different proportions of reactants can lead to different ratios of the three-atom bridges (i.e. the greater the proportion of NaN3, the larger the value of x is), reactions with greatly excessive or without NaN3 had also been tried. It is interesting that when an excess amount of NaN3 was used, yellow precipitate resulted, which was a previously reported structure of [Mn(II)(2,2'-bpy)(N3)2], with alternative EE (end-to-end, μ1,3) and EO (end-on, μ1,1) azide bridges in the space group of P1̅ (Figure ). In the absence of NaN3 or replacing Mn(HCO2)2 with Ni(HCO2)2/Cu(HCO2)2, crystalline powders other than phases 1-3 were obtained. The above experiments illustrate the spontaneous resolution process cannot occur without either of the three-atom bridges.

elements.content: FT-IR spectra of 1, 2, and 3. The peak intensities of ν(HCO2 –) were normalized.
elements.clean_text: 1  FT-IR spectra of 1, 2, and 3. The peak intensities of ν(HCO2 -) were normalized.

elements.content: Single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction experiments (pXRD) () indicated that 1, 2, and 3 are a family of isostructural frameworks. Spontaneous resolution occurred during crystallization of 1–3, and two enantiomers for each compound, M- (minus or left-handed, 1-M, 2-M, and 3-M) and P- (plus or right-handed, 1-P, 2-P, and 3-P) helices (Figure ), were found to be crystallized in the chiral hexagonal space groups of P6522 and P6122, respectively. The Flack absolute structure parameters (Table ) clearly indicate the chirality of the molecules in the crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures

Single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction experiments (pXRD) () indicated that 1, 2, and 3 are a family of isostructural frameworks. Spontaneous resolution occurred during crystallization of 1-3, and two enantiomers for each compound, M- (minus or left-handed, 1-M, 2-M, and 3-M) and P- (plus or right-handed, 1-P, 2-P, and 3-P) helices (Figure ), were found to be crystallized in the chiral hexagonal space groups of P6522 and P6122, respectively. The Flack absolute structure parameters (Table ) clearly indicate the chirality of the molecules in the crystals.

elements.content: Top: View of the coordination environment of Mn(II) in 3-M (left) and 3-P (right) with 30% thermal ellipsoids (H atoms are omitted for clarity). Color code: Mn(II), purple; O, red; N, blue; C, black. Middle: The axially chiral conformations of 2,2′-bpy and the angle between two pyridine rings in 3-M (left) and 3-P (right). Bottom: Arrangement of helix structures in 3-M and 3-P.
elements.clean_text: 2  Top: View of the coordination environment of Mn(II) in 3-M (left) and 3-P (right) with 30% thermal ellipsoids (H atoms are omitted for clarity). Color code: Mn(II), purple; O, red; N, blue; C, black. Middle: The axially chiral conformations of 2,2'-bpy and the angle between two pyridine rings in 3-M (left) and 3-P (right). Bottom: Arrangement of helix structures in 3-M and 3-P.

elements.content: The Mn(II) adopts an octahedral geometry surrounded by two nondisordered HCO2 – on the axial positions of the coordination sphere, one chelating 2,2′-bpy ligand, and two disordered N3 – or HCO2 – in the cis-positions on the equatorial plane. The {Mn(2,2′-bpy)}2+ motifs are connected by the axial nondisordered HCO2 – bridges into helical chains along the c-direction, with the screw-pitch equal to the length of the c-axis (19.9 Å). The helices are linked together by the disordered three-atom N3 – or HCO2 – bridges to form a three-dimensional chiral framework in an NbO-net topology with a Schäfli symbol of 64·82 and a long vertex symbol 62·62·6·6·87·87 by OLEX analysis when considering the Mn(II) ions as 4-connected nodes in a seesaw geometry (Figure ). The 2-fold rotate axes lie through Mn1, and the center of 2,2′-bpy, while the 65 and 61 axes go through the center of the helices of the M- and P-compounds, respectively. No obvious hydrogen bonding interactions are found in 1–3.
elements.clean_text: The Mn(II) adopts an octahedral geometry surrounded by two nondisordered HCO2 - on the axial positions of the coordination sphere, one chelating 2,2'-bpy ligand, and two disordered N3 - or HCO2 - in the cis-positions on the equatorial plane. The {Mn(2,2'-bpy)}2+ motifs are connected by the axial nondisordered HCO2 - bridges into helical chains along the c-direction, with the screw-pitch equal to the length of the c-axis (19.9 Å). The helices are linked together by the disordered three-atom N3 - or HCO2 - bridges to form a three-dimensional chiral framework in an NbO-net topology with a Schäfli symbol of 64⋅82 and a long vertex symbol 62⋅62⋅6⋅6⋅87⋅87 by OLEX analysis when considering the Mn(II) ions as 4-connected nodes in a seesaw geometry (Figure ). The 2-fold rotate axes lie through Mn1, and the center of 2,2'-bpy, while the 65 and 61 axes go through the center of the helices of the M- and P-compounds, respectively. No obvious hydrogen bonding interactions are found in 1-3.

elements.content: All the possibilities of the coordination environment of Mn(II) for 1–3, two of which (d and e) are potentially chiral. But only a, b, and c are possible in our case.
elements.clean_text: 4  All the possibilities of the coordination environment of Mn(II) for 1-3, two of which (d and e) are potentially chiral. But only a, b, and c are possible in our case.

elements.content: As N3 – or HCO2 – are substitutional disordered on the equatorial plane, the Mn(II) ions may have three coordination environments, due to different combinations of N3 – or HCO2 – (Figure a–c). Mirror plane symmetry can be found on the equatorial planes for all three geometries and running perpendicularly across 2,2′-bpy for a and c. Accordingly, the metal atoms are not stereogenic centers and not responsible for the chirality of the frameworks. As shown in Figure , among all the possible coordination environments for Mn(II), only d and e are potentially chiral with Λ- and Δ-configurations. It is apparently not the case for 1–3, because the nondisordered formates are not in the cis-positions.
elements.clean_text: As N3 - or HCO2 - are substitutional disordered on the equatorial plane, the Mn(II) ions may have three coordination environments, due to different combinations of N3 - or HCO2 - (Figure a-c). Mirror plane symmetry can be found on the equatorial planes for all three geometries and running perpendicularly across 2,2'-bpy for a and c. Accordingly, the metal atoms are not stereogenic centers and not responsible for the chirality of the frameworks. As shown in Figure , among all the possible coordination environments for Mn(II), only d and e are potentially chiral with Λ- and Δ-configurations. It is apparently not the case for 1-3, because the nondisordered formates are not in the cis-positions.

elements.content: As mentioned previously, 2,2′-bpy is achiral because of the free rotation of the σ-bond between two pyridine rings. It becomes an important element of chirality in 1–3, in that the two axially chiral conformations of λ and δ are “locked” in the crystals of 1-M, 2-M, and 3-M or 1-P, 2-P, and 3-P, respectively. In addition, the angle between two pyridine rings is quite significant (up to 25.6°, Figure ). The chiral conformations of 2,2′-bpy captured in [Mn(II)(2,2′-bpy)(HCO2)2–x (N3) x ] lead to the formation of an M- or P-helix and the coexistence of both molecular and supramolecular chirality.
elements.clean_text: As mentioned previously, 2,2'-bpy is achiral because of the free rotation of the σ-bond between two pyridine rings. It becomes an important element of chirality in 1-3, in that the two axially chiral conformations of λ and δ are "locked" in the crystals of 1-M, 2-M, and 3-M or 1-P, 2-P, and 3-P, respectively. In addition, the angle between two pyridine rings is quite significant (up to 25.6°, Figure ). The chiral conformations of 2,2'-bpy captured in [Mn(II)(2,2'-bpy)(HCO2)2-x (N3) x ] lead to the formation of an M- or P-helix and the coexistence of both molecular and supramolecular chirality.

elements.content: Individual crystals of 3-M and 3-P were characterized with solid-state CD spectra in KCl pellets (Figure ). Cotton effects are obviously observed for each single crystal of 3-M and 3-P, showing two positive peaks at 310 and 259 nm, as well as one negative peak at 283 nm for 3-M and the peaks with opposite signals at the same wavelengths for 3-P. Similar Cotton effects were also observed for 1 and 2, confirming the spontaneous resolution process.
elements.clean_text: Individual crystals of 3-M and 3-P were characterized with solid-state CD spectra in KCl pellets (Figure ). Cotton effects are obviously observed for each single crystal of 3-M and 3-P, showing two positive peaks at 310 and 259 nm, as well as one negative peak at 283 nm for 3-M and the peaks with opposite signals at the same wavelengths for 3-P. Similar Cotton effects were also observed for 1 and 2, confirming the spontaneous resolution process.

elements.content: Single-crystal CD spectra in KCl pellets of 3-M (solid line) and 3-P (dash line).
elements.clean_text: 5  Single-crystal CD spectra in KCl pellets of 3-M (solid line) and 3-P (dash line).

elements.content: The two three-atom bridges have distinctive geometries; that is, HCO2 – is curving while N3 – is linear. The cooperation between these two ligands plays important roles in assembling the chiral 3-D frameworks and “grasping” the axially chiral conformations of 2,2′-bpy. It is clear that the spontaneous resolution process cannot occur without either of the three-atom bridging ligands for the previous discussion. The above work rules out the possibility that the sample is a mixture with only either kind of ligands in each individual crystal instead of mixed bridges. Meanwhile, ratio of N3 –/HCO2 – can be facilely tuned by using different proportions of reactants, which provides some possibilities to tune magnetic exchange considering different magnetic coupling magnitudes for HCO2 – and N3 – bridges.
elements.clean_text: The two three-atom bridges have distinctive geometries; that is, HCO2 - is curving while N3 - is linear. The cooperation between these two ligands plays important roles in assembling the chiral 3-D frameworks and "grasping" the axially chiral conformations of 2,2'-bpy. It is clear that the spontaneous resolution process cannot occur without either of the three-atom bridging ligands for the previous discussion. The above work rules out the possibility that the sample is a mixture with only either kind of ligands in each individual crystal instead of mixed bridges. Meanwhile, ratio of N3 -/HCO2 - can be facilely tuned by using different proportions of reactants, which provides some possibilities to tune magnetic exchange considering different magnetic coupling magnitudes for HCO2 - and N3 - bridges.

elements.content: Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements (2–300 K) at 1 kOe dc field were carried out for 1, 2, and 3. As shown in Figure , the χM T values of 1, 2, and 3 are 4.14, 4.14, and 4.08 cm3 K mol–1, respectively, at 300 K, slightly smaller than the spin-only value (4.38 cm3 K mol–1) for an S = 5/2 Mn(II) ion (taking g = 2.00). When lowering the temperature, the χM T products decrease monotonically to 0.49, 0.29, and 0.24 cm3 K mol–1 for 1, 2, and 3 at 2 K, respectively. A fit of the experimental data to a Curie–Weiss law (Figures and ) leads to the Weiss constants θ of −21.6, −29.2, and −35.4 K for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. According to molecular field theory, θ = 2S(S + 1)zJ/3k (where z = 4 here for considering Mn(II) as 4-connected nodes of NbO net topology, k is the Boltzmann constant), and the calculating magnetic exchange constants (J) are −0.64 for 1, −0.87 for 2, and −1.05 cm–1 for 3. These results confirm the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling among Mn(II) ions and suggest that the larger x value favors the more negative exchange constant. Additionally, the M–H plots are consistent with this order (Figure ), observing no saturation (5Nβ) as well as the decay of magnetization with the increase of x value.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements (2-300 K) at 1 kOe dc field were carried out for 1, 2, and 3. As shown in Figure , the χM T values of 1, 2, and 3 are 4.14, 4.14, and 4.08 cm3 K mol-1, respectively, at 300 K, slightly smaller than the spin-only value (4.38 cm3 K mol-1) for an S = 5/2 Mn(II) ion (taking g = 2.00). When lowering the temperature, the χM T products decrease monotonically to 0.49, 0.29, and 0.24 cm3 K mol-1 for 1, 2, and 3 at 2 K, respectively. A fit of the experimental data to a Curie-Weiss law (Figures  and ) leads to the Weiss constants θ of -21.6, -29.2, and -35.4 K for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. According to molecular field theory, θ = 2S(S + 1)zJ/3k (where z = 4 here for considering Mn(II) as 4-connected nodes of NbO net topology, k is the Boltzmann constant), and the calculating magnetic exchange constants (J) are -0.64 for 1, -0.87 for 2, and -1.05 cm-1 for 3. These results confirm the presence of antiferromagnetic coupling among Mn(II) ions and suggest that the larger x value favors the more negative exchange constant. Additionally, the M-H plots are consistent with this order (Figure ), observing no saturation (5Nβ) as well as the decay of magnetization with the increase of x value.

elements.content: Left: Plots of χM T vs T for 1 (open box), 2 (open circle), and 3 (open triangle), and plots of χM vs T for 1 (solid box), 2 (solid circle), and 3 (solid triangle). The solid lines are the best fits of the experimental data to a Curie–Weiss law in the temperature range 100–300 K, and then extrapolate to 20 K. Right: Plots of M–H for 1 (solid box), 2 (solid circle), and 3 (solid triangle) at 2 K.
elements.clean_text: 6  Left: Plots of χM T vs T for 1 (open box), 2 (open circle), and 3 (open triangle), and plots of χM vs T for 1 (solid box), 2 (solid circle), and 3 (solid triangle). The solid lines are the best fits of the experimental data to a Curie-Weiss law in the temperature range 100-300 K, and then extrapolate to 20 K. Right: Plots of M-H for 1 (solid box), 2 (solid circle), and 3 (solid triangle) at 2 K.

elements.content: The coupling among Mn(II) is dominantly antiferromagnetic when bridging by EE N3 – or HCO2 – ligands. Furthermore, the EE azido bridge is stronger coupling than the formate one, as found in two 3D pcu frameworks, [Mn(II)(HCO2)3]− (J = −0.19 cm–1) and [Mn(II)(N3)3]− (J = −1.73 cm–1). Compounds 1, 2, and 3 fall in this range and show that the larger the x value, the stronger the antiferromagnetic coupling (Figure ). In this context, we have successfully tuned the magnetic exchange via easily changing the ratios of the three-atom bridges.
elements.clean_text: The coupling among Mn(II) is dominantly antiferromagnetic when bridging by EE N3 - or HCO2 - ligands. Furthermore, the EE azido bridge is stronger coupling than the formate one, as found in two 3D pcu frameworks, [Mn(II)(HCO2)3]- (J = -0.19 cm-1) and [Mn(II)(N3)3]- (J = -1.73 cm-1). Compounds 1, 2, and 3 fall in this range and show that the larger the x value, the stronger the antiferromagnetic coupling (Figure ). In this context, we have successfully tuned the magnetic exchange via easily changing the ratios of the three-atom bridges.

elements.content: Plot of the magnetic exchange constant, J, vs the ratio of three-atom bridges, x (△ and ○ are from refs and and our work in this article, respectively).
elements.clean_text: 7  Plot of the magnetic exchange constant, J, vs the ratio of three-atom bridges, x (△ and ○ are from refs   and   and our work in this article, respectively).

elements.content: In summary, a family of chiral 3-dimensional frameworks with NbO net topology were synthesized through spontaneous resolution from the solution reactions using achiral reactants. It is interesting that the axially chiral conformations of 2,2′-bpy are captured upon coordination and result in chirality for the compounds. By changing the ratios of the three-atom bridging ligands, magnetic exchange can be successfully tuned. The disordered bridges play a vital role in the spontaneous resolution process and magnetic coupling, providing an excellent example for understanding the chiral compounds and the magnetic interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a family of chiral 3-dimensional frameworks with NbO net topology were synthesized through spontaneous resolution from the solution reactions using achiral reactants. It is interesting that the axially chiral conformations of 2,2'-bpy are captured upon coordination and result in chirality for the compounds. By changing the ratios of the three-atom bridging ligands, magnetic exchange can be successfully tuned. The disordered bridges play a vital role in the spontaneous resolution process and magnetic coupling, providing an excellent example for understanding the chiral compounds and the magnetic interactions.

cln_elements.content:
Safety Note: Azide salts are potentially explosive. Only small amounts of material should be prepared, and these should be handled with great caution.

Synthesis of [Mn(II)(2,2′-bpy)(HCO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2–<italic toggle="yes">x</italic> </sub>(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub> <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> </sub>] (<bold>1</bold>, <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> = 0.3; <bold>2</bold>, <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> = 0.6; and <bold>3</bold>, <italic toggle="yes">x</italic> = 0.7)

2,2′-bpy and NaN3 were dissolved in 20 mL of methanol in an ultrasonic bath, and then the mixture was added to Mn(HCO2)2. After stirring for half an hour, the white solid was dissolved and turned yellowish. Yellow crystals of 1–3 were obtained via filtration in ∼30% yield based on Mn(HCO2)2. The ratios of the reactants of 2,2′-bipyridine, NaN3, and Mn(HCO2)2 are 4:1:4, 3:1:3, and 2:1:2, respectively, giving 1, 2, and 3. Anal. Calcd for 1: N, 13.53; C, 46.80; H, 3.26. Found: N, 13.50; C, 45.21; H, 3.36. Anal. Calcd for 2: N, 17.78; C, 45.74; H, 3.16. Found: N, 17.53; C, 45.51; H, 3.24. Anal. Calcd for 3: N, 19.20; C, 45.38; H, 3.13. Found: N, 18.99; C, 44.78; H, 3.50.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Safety Note: Azide salts are potentially explosive. Only small amounts of material should be prepared, and these should be handled with great caution.

Synthesis of [Mn(II)(2,2'-bpy)(HCO2)2-x (N3) x ] (1, x = 0.3; 2, x = 0.6; and 3, x = 0.7)

2,2'-bpy and NaN3 were dissolved in 20 mL of methanol in an ultrasonic bath, and then the mixture was added to Mn(HCO2)2. After stirring for half an hour, the white solid was dissolved and turned yellowish. Yellow crystals of 1-3 were obtained via filtration in ~30% yield based on Mn(HCO2)2. The ratios of the reactants of 2,2'-bipyridine, NaN3, and Mn(HCO2)2 are 4:1:4, 3:1:3, and 2:1:2, respectively, giving 1, 2, and 3. Anal. Calcd for 1: N, 13.53; C, 46.80; H, 3.26. Found: N, 13.50; C, 45.21; H, 3.36. Anal. Calcd for 2: N, 17.78; C, 45.74; H, 3.16. Found: N, 17.53; C, 45.51; H, 3.24. Anal. Calcd for 3: N, 19.20; C, 45.38; H, 3.13. Found: N, 18.99; C, 44.78; H, 3.50.

metadata.title:
Capturing Axially Chiral Conformations of 2,2′-bipyridine in [Mn(II)(2,2′-bpy)(HCO2)2–x
(N3)
x
] via Spontaneous Resolution
